div.l: And ther with al he lough and made good chere
And saide his tale as ȝe shal after here
¶ Thus endeth þe ꝓprologe /
And now bigynneth þe tale~
A Prentys whilom dwelled in oure Cite
And of a craft of vitaillers was he
Gaylard he was as goldfynche in þe shawe
Broıı̄un as a berie a ꝓpropir short felawe
With lokkes blake / y kempt ful fetisly
Daunce he couthe so wel and iolily
That he was /cleped Perkyn Reuelour
He was as ful of loue and paramour
As is þe hyue / ful of hony swete
Wel was þe þe wenche with hym myghte mete
At eủery bridale / wolde he synge and hoppe
He loued bet þe tauerne þan þe shoppe
For whan ther eny ridyng was in chepe
Out of the shoppe / thider wolde he lepe
Til þat he hadde / al þe sighte yseyn
And daunced wel / wolde he not come ageyn
He gadered hym a meyne of his sort
To hoppe and synge / and make such disport
And there þei sette steuene for to mete
To pleyen atte dys / in such a strete
For in þe toıı̄un was þer no prentys
That fairer couthe caste a peyre of dys
Than ꝑperkyn couthe / and þer to he was fre
Of his dispence / in place of pⁱriuite
That fond his maister / ful wel in his chaffare
For ofte tyme he fond his box ful bare
For sikerly a p̉rentys reuelour
That haunteth dys / riot or ꝑparamour
His maister shal it in his shoppe abye
Al haue he no part of the mynstralcie
For thefte and riot / they be inconủertible
Al can he pleye / on git̉erne or ribible
Reuel and trouthe / as in lowe degree
They ben ful wrothe / alday as men may see
This Ioly prentys / with his maist̉er bood
